intro: Haplopappus eastwoodiae, commonly known as the Eastwood's pappus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive bracts. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to harsh, dry climates. Its small, yellow flowers bloom in the spring, and the plant produces a fluffy pappus that aids in seed dispersal. Haplopappus eastwoodiae is relatively rare and is of interest to botanists due to its unique ecological niche and limited distribution.
